Early Access Review
 Introduction After playing this studio's previous entry and liking the aesthetics and tone (Dungeons of Dredmor), I was pleasently surprised that they have since been working on another game that follows similiar themes but was a RTS instead of a rouge-like. Intrigued, decided to place this game on my wishlist and see how the development would pan out. After more than a year and finding myself pining for a new RTS to play, decided to give this entry a go despite the price tag. A decision based on research and seeing the company was committed to continous development and fixes based on player feedback. Comparing this to how other Early Access games are treated by their companies, this bolstered my confidence, ultimately resulting in a purchase.However of course, this being an Early Access game, the game itself is not without it's faults and I will try to give an balanced view to the current state of the game as of it's latest state: Build 52.------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Actually Playing  Graphics Aesthetic-wise the game doesn't use high polygon graphics with models and textures looking a little on the muddy side but does it's job well enough to easily identify what you're looking at. I rarely found myself being confused by what a item was based on looks alone, unless it was a new item I haven't encountered yet. Music The current iteration of the music loops through a few tracks which have a nice spooky, ethereal feel to them, very much in line with the overall lovecraftian feel of the game. The music on/off function in the options didn't work for me, so if you want to silence the game while you listen to your own tunes, this is not currently possible in the current iteration of the game. Controls Controls are done with the W, A, S, D keys to moe left, right, up and down the map by default, E and Q keys rotate the camera. Wasn't a problem for me but did read a review earlier where someone expressed their displeasure at the lack of mouse-camera control scheme so might be negative for you depending on your preference.  Gameplay As for the gameplay itself, it's fairly typical of entries into this genre with the game starting out at a location of your choosing and whatever starting loadout of populace and supplies you choose, from there it's up to you to build up your settlement from working with wood and foraging for food to creating metal plates and pipes and growing your own form of sustenance as well as creating a militia to fend off foreign threats.The game itself is quite fun and you can easily lose hours of your life dedicating to building up your populace from humble beginnings however there are a few points you have to consider before you decide to buy into this Early Access.1. The pacing of the game is significantly slower than other entries i've tried in the genre. It can take you up to 2-3 hours to get your first couple of houses built, crops to reach their first harvest and to have a working carpentry and kitchen with new workers and overseers trickling in a very gradual rate. Workers and overseers seem to take forever to get anything done with the populace just walking at a very casual almost plodding pace and I found myself alt-tabbing out of the game often because they were either asleep or it just felt it was taking too long for something to be built because the game wasn't clear on what a worker was waiting on to fulfill a order or what task they were working on instead.An example of this was when I was waiting for some iron ingots to be made, which required both Coal and Hematite, both of which i had enough for but for some reason despite neither being on break, my overseer of the metalworks decided tidying the store for the upteenth time was more important with the other worker off talking to their friend.2. Unlike other games i've played in this genre, your typical overseers and workers who carry out your orders and fuel the economic and technogical growth of your operation have shifts which they stick to, working typically for most of the day with needed rests in the middle and end of their shift. They can work extra for longer shifts if they're happier and this current iteration is a marked improvement over earlier builds of the game where downtime was more paramount but is still a point of contention when talking about the game's pacing.Consdering these points, I'm afraid i'm going to have to agree with those who believe that a speed-dial option would be nice, although it can be peaceful and almost tranquil to watch my current settlement carry out their lives, I found myself falling asleep or alt-tabbing out the game to keep my attention engaged. The game's slow pacing is a sentiment I have seen repeated in other reviews. Bugs 3. Bugs. It's Early Access so they are to be expected and just like how programming typically is, for every little thing that is fixed and added, another bug rears it's head. The game can end up crashing entirely and there are weird glitches where stacks of resources are left and forgotten when construcing buildings, items being stuck in mid-animation e.g. when being picked up/placed down in stockpile as well workers/overseers picking up and placing items down continously as if they're stuck in some loop. Typically problems start cropping up when the population start getting past the 45 people range. Encountered another bug where a total of 2 workforce was sent to man an mineshaft and both work forces just disappeared so that was weird.Despite these flaws, I do still find myself coming back to play this game: a testament to the developer's vision but if you do pick up this game  and your patience is like mine, you may find yourself feeling frustrated starting a new map and realising it's going to take another 2-3 hours to feel like you're getting anywhere and the plodding pace of your populace is going to make you feel like getting up and making a cup of tea.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- In Closing To sum up, I'd say do give the game a go if you feel inclined, with few entries of RTS's of this type at the moment and the lack of feedback and apparent development from other games in Early Access i seen on here, it seems Gaslamp Games is committed and in for the long run with Clockwork Empires with them consistently pushing out fixes and updates every month.The community surrounding the game is also positive with little flaming and ban's going on which seems to speak volumes about the company's attitude, so if you haven't been deterred by the negative points I listed and want to support a company that seem committed to further development of this title then go for it I'd say. I do plan to keep the review pretty up to date as more builds come out, changes to my review will be made as applicable.Thank you for taking the time to read my review if you got to the end and I'd be happy to reply to any comments,

They’re aware of the “issues” in the genre and time period they’re working within, and they have constructed an experience that lambasts the silliest part of the Victorian era without celebrating the worst bits OR leaving them in there without comment for “accuracy” purposes. If it matters to you, Gaslamp are good people.*	META: Devs are accessible and there are a lot of tools in game for bug-chasing, due to its time in early access. Speaking from Early access, I’ve had bugs I reported fixed within a few hours and pushed to a build.The Bad:*	The pacing can be slow. It’s a sim game, and your people all have stuff to do. Sometimes you’re stuck watching your people do their thing and waiting for more colonists to arrive / jobs to complete / etc. There’s a lot of satisfaction in seeing everyone scurry around at your whim, but it can get old if you just want them to finish building cots or whatever.*	The hows and whys of flattening terrain are strange. I still haven’t figured them out. *	Overwhelming. There can be a lot to take in at once, and you need a few games to comfortable with all the options. This is especially early in the game when you don’t necessarily have the necessary workshops and people set up to do anything about it (like foreign offices or vicars). It’s kinda fun in its own way, but there can be a lot on screen at once with you not really being able to deal with any of it.Final Verdict:It’s really fun and all of these detailed randomized people have the potential to create both a very rich colony simulator, and very strange stories (like Zora and the Investigator).There’s lots of reviews that talk about the game not being “Finished”. It’s not, in the sense that there’s still a lot of room for growth and potential. But right now, the game is already well equipped to tell stories, and occupy you for hours. The stability is pretty good and it’s going to get better. (Heck, it’s already more stable than most AAA games are on launch, fallout 4, xcom 2, etc). If I had written this review 6 months ago, I wouldn’t have recommended it. I think it deserves to be out of Early Access now, as the game itself is complete. I know the devs will continue to add content (Look at their previous game – Dungeons of Dredmor, which had 3 expansion and free content updates throughout).This is a fun game! You should buy it!

												Biased review incoming.Huge fan of Gaslamp games since the early days of Dungeons of Dredmor.Been playing this game on and off for several years and watching its development.Seeing lots of complaints on how "lazy" the AI is.  The AI isn't that lazy, but there are systems in place that if you don't notice them, they will appear lazy.  For example the overseers and workers all take breaks during the day.  The happier they are, the shorter breaks they take.  How do you make them happy?  This partially depends on the individual, they all have quirks.  However, there are things that will make all of them happy in general.  Things such as safety (well-armed militia), workplace quality, housing quality, food quality, and public services such as a pub and/or church.Also assigning more tasks than there are roaming (not assigned to a building) overseers, then it will feel like nothing is getting done.As I said earlier, I've been playing this game a long time.  I don't remember having to learn the fairly complex UI because at one point it wasn't that complex.  But that made it too difficult to get things done.  I know it has a steep learning curve, but every failure helps you understand how to do it better next time.  Entire population wiped out by bandits?  Should have worked on militia earlier, built more homes, or taken them out first.  Run out of food?  Make production more efficient by putting the kitchen right next to the farm, or build a naturalist's building and have them hunt for game.There are many routes to go in this game, most are up to personal preference.Also, the game has a pause button (spacebar) during which you can manage multiple things while the game-time is frozen.  Abuse this power.Bottom line:  If you have the time and patience, this game is great for long-term entertainment.  Enjoy the tongue-in-cheek nature and don't take it too seriously.

								Inspired by reading a certain article about Early Access Games, I thought about Clockwork Empire and my oppinion of it.In general, as the thumb up indicates, I recommend and support this game. It is though very early in developement. The general concept is similar to other tactical, economical simulations game. Their gratest imrpove though is the idea of not having individuals appointed to all kinds of jobs by the engine, but to have a whole group do the tasks as one. This brings in the dynamic and speed often missing within the games, also it organizes the order of jobs and economoics.The idea and setting of the game is also one I highly appreciate, for it promises to become a very well done steam-punk game, whereof there is way too little on the market in my oppinion. At least in this sort of genre, mind you. Already there are a lot of interesting mechanics in the order of production and economoy to be seen in the early access, and I look forward to see what else they might include.Then there is the studio and their individual personallity, mirrored in the story and character of the game. Their humor is awesome and I loved it all the time when playing Dungeons of Dreadmore. It is because of this former game that I went into early access with a lot of trust and faith in this studio! They might have chosen a more tricky set up of a game here, but their idea - or the one I see from the game - is that of a semi mysterius-industrial culture simulation game, with a lot of humor. Thanks to that I see an interesting game evolve here, that will have lots of things to offer for people who enjoyed to play Dwarf Fortress, Gnomoria, Facturio and the like. At least, in my point of view. Like other Early-Access Projects they do well on including content step by step and simultanously balancing and fixing or repairing priviosly included stuff and mechanics. Also the game-concept itself can be viewed as object-oriented. That is important on a perspective of game developeing: Since it is OO, they >can< take concepts and content of the game and put it into a later phase of the developing. Where other games might fail because the developers have too much to synch at the same time and write together, here there is the option to evolve step by step, which is crucially important.Again, this is just my oppinion, based on what I see as a player, without having actually peaked into the code yet. For anyone interested, all you as a buyer need to have is pacience. So far I had a good nose with my picks, and this is one that will grow slowly but steadyly. 								I've been following CE for a few years now, and feel that Beta 55 is where the game's finally hit its stride and is a clean recommend for any fan of city "managers" in the vein of Dwarf Fortress, Rimworld, Gnomoria, and their ilk.The pace of the game is steady, as you start from a small batch of overseers and workers and build up your colony. 												Ok well, here is my 2 cents. I bought clockwork empires before release but not as early as some other people. I am going to recommend this game overall but with one major caveat. Onwards to my review!The concept is brilliant, a colony sim in a Lovecraftian steampunk nightmare. The concept is delivered well with plenty of building options, other denizens of the area to either destroy in xenophobic genocide or merely tolerate, a resource system that is a breath of fresh air in comparison to the traditional groups of nodes or tunnelling into the earth directly. The crop system appears to be missing alot however if you spend a little time with the diplomacy you will find that allied trading partners may bring the option to grow other plants from other biomes along with your own research in the laboratory. The science aspect is developed yet simple however leaves too much rng for my tastes with the initial research options, i feel a more traditional tree similar to the Civ games would be more suitable however, but still using the 3 focuses to make it a decision whether to subjegate using advanced military might or develop your money making power with cash crops and dominate in the diplomacy arena.Combat is simple affair with equipping your squads with different gear as you unlock and craft it and then either letting them patrol the general area or directing them to specific points, possibly having the choice of equipping individual squad members with different weapons .I know I am making suggestions but bear with me, The biggest problem with this game is the restrictive manpower assignment process. You have overseers or foremen and labourers. You assign an overseer to a position within a production building and then assign labourers. Any work that is being carried out will be completed but lets say your carpenters are finished work and are just loafing around but your farmers require more help getting the crop in this season or the colony requires a tidy up then the carpenters will not do anything other than what is in the order queue for the workshop. To solve this I would say that maybe having clearing and land flattening common to all trades but so low on the priority list that it is used as filler when they have nothing better to do. Some people have a problem with the fact that the game has released with either not enough content, or not enough of this that or the other. I feel that the negative reviews are doing the opposite of what the possible intent may be. I am reccommending this game on the fact that with continued support then only then can it grow. I enjoy playing this game and do not wish to see it die like so many other indie productions, however the community has been burned by too many time wasters and is now over critical of any independant producers by expecting games that require nothing more added to it at release, look at bethesda and fallout 4 when that released, EA with simcity, AAA producers make mistakes yet they have the monetry backing to weather a community backlash. Indie producers do not, and require a different form of criticsm, one where as a community we still recommend the hard work but still temper it with helpful criticsm.I appologise for the review turn rant but one of the biggest reasons indie games fail is because the community kills them. Why continue putting blood, sweat and tears into something to be put to the steak and burned.

												A quirky little simulator, Clockwork Empires is a ton of fun, and one of those games that you can play for a very long time. Like Gaslamp's last game, Dungeons of Dredmor, it offers a ton of replayability, a bright and offbeat aesthetic, and excelletn player support and communication. Hopefully, like Dredmor, it will have years of free updates and community mods lavished upon it. You start a settlement in a strange new Victorian world, try not to starve, improve the lives of your colonists, and slowly grow your camp into a thriving town. Deal with local fishpeople as you see fit! Meddle in the affairs of foreign empres, either trough trade or violence! Same goes for bandits and those with dissenting ideas! A lot of the joy in this game comes from the ant-farm appeal. You tell them what needs doing, but these little colonists run around having lives of theri own, full of strangeness and emotional turmoil. It's a joy sometimes just to let things run and watch them go about their business, getting♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off by their boss, going to the pub to calm down, gossiping with their friends and then having to run for their lives as an eldritch horror tries to rip their face off. The other joy is the level of freedom the game gives you in terms of construction. The entiire world is deformable, meaning you can alter all the land to suit your needs. You can also build just about any building shape and size you want, and fill it with whatever assortment of gear it needs to run or to be a bizzare trap for it's inhabitants. While there are still some rough edges in the UI and AI, this is a complicated labor of love made by a very small, very hard-working team. It is definately feature complete and ready to play, but you can be sure that it will only be improved over time. Gaslamp Games stays with it's games, and does right by the people who play them. This in a big and ambitious step for them, and I hope you'll give it a try. I did, and it's made it's way into my heart.

												I am recommending this, but only for certain people. You need to know going in that this was a very ambitious game, and while they sort of pulled it off there is a lot that they didn't get to, and it does feel unpolished. There's a lot wrong with this game, but I actually do love it, and I feel that I will keep coming back to it for a long time. Particularly if it is updated. I think the reason this game has turned out the way it has is because the devs waded into uncharted territory without a map. They get a lot of points from me for doing something different. A lot of what has been done is very innovative, and if you are a fan of this genre you will love playing with the highly customisable workshops, houses and special buildings. It's great fun drawing a blueprint for your carpenters workshop and deciding where everything will go - you feel like you are building a colony from scratch rather than just planting down premade buildings. The work crew system is unique and while I have a few issues with it, the idea is good. You have a supervisor who can employ up to four people. Those four labourers will join the supervisor on whatever task they are assigned to (you do this based on their traits and skills) and their effectiveness is determined by a few things including the skill of the supervisor, the buiding quality... and probably some other nebulous thing I haven't figured out yet. From that example you can probably see that you need to invest some time in order to understand the complex systems going on. It's not obvious. This is for people like me who actually enjoy figuring that stuff out and find it really satisfying to understand a complex system enough to be able to build something thriving.What I want to add to all of the reviews so far (including the negative ones that make good points) is that there is huge potential for fun here.  If you took a look at Dwarf Fortress and thought you couldn't handle figuring it out, maybe skip this. If the reason you skipped Dwarf Fortress was solely down to graphics, hey, this could be a gold mine for you.

												The game features randomly generated maps in different biomes with no overall objective, other than survival and expansion. While the interface allows for multiple ways of finding information (like building queues), being able to queue up multiple projects on the same module would be helpful. In addition, being able to search for resources on the map would be a welcome feature. Overseers perform as managers, working in a building or picking available tasks (like chopping trees, foraging for food, or mining surface rocks) on a specific daily schedule; laborers are attached to an overseer and will automatically assist. Each colonist has extensive memories of past events that dictate their levels of happiness, despair, anger, and fear, which in turn affect their ability to work. Colonists will also level up at specific skills they routinely perform, making them better at their job. Raw resources are collected from the landscape, grown in farms, or mined. These are processed in different buildings on various pieces of equipment; the building layouts are custom designed by the player, allowing for different plans based on current needs and giving a more varied look to the colony. Multi-step production in Clockwork Empires is interesting, although the steps and equipment required for make a specific good may not be intuitive. Other factions in the area may be friendly or hostile; trade can be initiated to secure goods that are not plentiful at your location, and enemy factions can invade your colony. Strange beasts roam the landscape and terrorize the colonists, and cults may form when citizen behaviors warrant them. While the early game is fairly repetitive (the same initial structures are used every time) and some aspects of the user interface could be improved, Clockwork Empires is a very compelling management game thanks to its distinctive theme, detailed citizens, customized building layouts, multi-step item production, and hostile environment.

												The game, as in the gameplay itself is very good. The best I've played in years when it comes to this kind of genre actually. However as most people are saying, the game is a bit glitchy and buggy. And there's little to no graphics options, and the game starts chugging when your colony grows in size, even as primitive as the actual models in the game are.Also the water looks weird.--Graphics--Other than that, I myself think the game looks great, the artstyle and textures are easy to look at and conveys the information from the gameworld that you need for the most part. It is also surprisingly detailed texture-wize and all the different resources and furniture have distinct models.The GUI is 4 out of 5 I think for this kind of game. Lots of tooltips and easy to distinguish thumbnails and menus. However there are a few instances where some improvement would be appreciated. For example:-The minimap have no indicator of where your camera is, and does not rotate together with you. I don't know if this is a gamedesign decision or not, but it's certainly abnormal for this kind of game. You get used to it after about an hour of playtime, so it's no big deal.-I find it hard to manage overseers and their workplaces when I get a good number of them. Comparing Overseers and finding their stats are cumbersome in some instances. Also the scrollbar sometimes snap back when scrolling through your people, so you can't scroll down the bottom one before it snaps back up to the top. This can be bruteforce-fixed by pausing the game. And it doesn't happen often.-It would be great with more visually distinct tooltips explaining that something has to be researched before you can build it.The game really needs some graphics options though. --Gameplay--The game is somewhat difficult, your guys can die really fast if things get out of hand. I'm sure if you read up on the most effective ways of building your colony it will be much easier, but figuring all that out is the fun of the game IMO.The game feel very deep and varied compared to other games. Not only in the same genre, but most games I play these days. There's 10 times more value here than say SW: Battlefront. For some reason that game came to mind.The progression is interesting and fun. You don't get all your stuff at once and have to research and get the correct resources before you can build specific things. Which is something I enjoy in this kind of game. Compared to say Prison Architect which I think did a poor job in that department. You have to do this all while avoiding all the dangers that surround you in this newfound land. Looking around at the map and observing the details is not only fun, but helpfull to your gameplay. Most of the things that your colonists experience in dialogue boxes can be seen in some way in the world. Like Cultists setting up a shrine nearby, so if you see a lot of candles in the forest, that's probably where they at.------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Even with it's glitches and crashes I've had a fun 24 or so hours with this game, and I'm not 10% into the game from what I can see.Here are some of the unintended features, bugs, glitches and crashes and other technical stuff that may detract from your experience. I myself did not care much, but I really hope the devs fix it up. It will probably be much more enjoyable.-Every so often the game just hardcrashes. I can't find any patterns to it, so I have to spend 30 seconds looking at youtube while it starts up again.-Saving the game takes a bit longer than I would like. I don't expect it to be instant, just a bit faster.-During my first time playing, my laboratory glitched out on an event, and became unusable, I couldn't even raze the building, or get my overseer unassigned from it. So I wasn't able to research anything. It became very confusing to me how to get stuff (like steel) That you have to research.- Skeletons and bodies are difficult to click on.- When placing walls, (military walls- I forget what they're called) sometimes I can't remove them before they're built.So I have to dismantle them later.- Water looks horrid. Just flatten it. Flatten it out of existance so you wont have to look at it.-Sometimes carpets disappear into the floor. It still gives its effect though.

content:

Early Access Review
								Alright, this game is in beta supposedly, and according to the developers is nearing full release. It's an indie game and costs about 1/2 as much as the Witcher 3. So is it at least 1/2 as good a value as the witcher 3? No, not even one tenth. Is it polished enough to issue it as a finished game? No. In fact I would dare say it's currently in alpha. It's broken and rough, for instance if you go into the options menue you risk being overwhelmed by the plethora of choices, such as music; On or Off. That's right, On or Off. Do you want to change the volume? No problem, just exit onto the main menue and... Oh wait, you can't, you need to exit the game, then restart it, and THEN on that starting screen you can change the volume. But not much else. Every time the game loads, you're pretty much past the point of certain that is has crashed again (nothing moves, the music stops), and THEN it starts.Betas can work, as long as you've got a somewhat stable and solid setup. Clockwork Empires combines the helplessness and slow♥♥♥♥♥pace of the Settlers with a grueling difficulty level close to that of Banished. The AI or AS rather, is what you find yourself relying on, yet it fails again and again to complete even the simplest of tasks, creating bottlenecks and downward spirals for your colonies. I've seen them wasting days picking things  up and dropping them, picking them up and dropping them, again and again. And you wonder why that vital building project isn't being built, that's why. I've seen them pick up resources and then heading out into the wilderness to gather more of said resource. Because whenever I go out to gather stones, I always bring some heavy boulders with me, because why not. It only gets better when said colonist gets spooked by some wildlife, drops the resources in the middle of nowhere and runs back home empty handed. The cooks finish meals only to gobble them down the second after and just, wow. I could go on.There's no prioritizing certain projects, unless you want to pause every other project, and even then with a work crew assigned to do just about everything, they're still mostly Idle, chatting away, and eating ten times their body weight, doing pretty much everything except the one thing you need them to.In 10hours, I've played 2 Colonies. Only 2 you say? Yes, because this game is SLOW! There's no fastforward button, buildings are erected in real time, colonists plod along in a zombie like pace etc. In both cases I've found that starvation is very hard to counteract, mostly because you don't start with any staple crops. The first time I started in the arctics, could grow nothing but cabbages; they sowed, reaped, and ate the produce right away while standing in the fields, didn't have the time to process or stockpile it. Hunting is unreliable, foraging doesn't yield enough, so what to do.The second time I started on a savannah, got chilli, tea and sugar. Does any of those sound like staple crops to you? At first I thought I could get by on hunting, but no. The meat dropped by the giant beetles apparently taste horrid and doesn't satisfy, and in either case isn't plentiful enough. Not even when they go cannibalistic do they manage to fill their bellies. Apparently eating a whole human isn't enough to satisfy their hunger needs once they're starving!Despite my best efforts to get along with the fishpeople, one of my moronic colonists went and raided one of their hatching piles when I wasn't looking and hadn't told him to, and as a result, I now get constant, endless, raiding parties whittling away at my starving colonists. My colonists' staple diet now consists of fishpeople steaks. Which they hate, and are STILL starving.When you need overseers you get workers, when you need workers you get overseers. There's always too much/too little of either or, and they apparently rely on different conditions. For instance, I managed to get a -66 relationship standing with my own empire using a diplomacy office (I kept asking for food, apparently they didn't like that). So now I never get any overseers, which means that if one of my current overseers die, I'm pretty screwed. You can't promote workers into overseers or anything like that, they are special snowflakes and if they die, which usually you have zero control over, it can be really bad. Again with the unstoppable downward spirals. Oh and you can't name the workteams either. So you can end up with The Happy Soldiers tending to a cabbage patch, and until they get skilled enough in farming, there's no quick way to see what they are doing without clicking on them (usually it just says Idle anyways, lazy bums). I get it, you have a high soldiering skill, but you're farmers now so shut up and farm.The game has plenty of those catch 22 moments that prevents you from enjoying it. In the savannah, there's apparently very little stone to be had, but it isn't obvious at first glance and I didn't know just how limited the colonists were in how far away they can move. I figured I needed a trade office to get stone. Guess what the trade office required to be built? Yes, stone. In the end, I solved it, but it's one of those cases where there's no way you could have known that it was going to be an issue and could have prepared for it in advance, since nobody told you. If you see a bunch of stone piles scattered around, you probably figure, hey I got stone, no problem. But you don't realize how little those piles actually yield in the end. And the tutorial only gives a generic runthrough (no mention of how to solve the food problem though), same for every enviroment, when it clearly shouldn't be.And you need to build a kitchen to cook. How bout a camp fire, and some tents for shelter that degrade over time. Who sends out colonists to sleep on the dirt and without proper crops to grow, apparently these people.So TLDR; it isn't balanced properly. And being forced to rely on the slow and moronic AI while nothing really happens that requires your attention, makes it that the game could just as easily be on standby without you. It isn't FUN to play is what I'm getting at. I can see a lot of potential with the idea, but some serious work is required to get it to a functioning level, and since the devs have the audacity to charge this much for a broken alpha version of the game and dare to say it's almost close to being finished; makes it so that I strongly doubt it will ever reach that potential.I would be happy if you prove me wrong though, so by all means, aim to do just that. But for now, for this price and claiming that it's almost finished when it's clearly not, gets a downvote from me.

I bought Clockwork Empires because it looked like a cool project, a Dwarf Fortress kind of game - a game that could produce the fascinating situations that arise from the complex interaction between your colonists and the enviroment they inhabit.I felt like I wrote a fair and balanced review, based on my experience with this game. 								-----------UpdateStill recommending you hold off on buying.I have figured out a big part of the problem.  The dev team needs to fix the pacing and needs management.You need too many facilities on day 1 and your settlers work much too slowly.  Keep in mind that you start with around 9 people and they all work SLOWLY.* You need a lower class house for everyone to sleep in.  Building it will take about 3 days.* You'll need a carpenter, which gets built relatively quickly but still a little too long. - And assign an overseer to it.* The lower class house will also need beds, so you'll need cloth, which means you also have to build a textile workshop (this is where it starts adding up) and assign an overseer to it.* In order to get the flax you need for cloth, you'll have to make a farm for it and assign an overseer wtih a team team to it. * Keep in mind, these buildings take stone and wood so you'll need to have overseers wtih teams gathering those as well. * You need to feed everyone so you have to build a kitchen and assign an overseer to it, preferrably with a team. * The kitchen needs food to cook so you'll need to make another farm and assign an overseer with a team to it. * There are going to be bandits and fish people attacking soon (even if you decide to avoid conflict, your people will seek it out) so you need to build a barracks and assign an overseer with a team to it. * The CONSTANT fighting is going to require the services of a Barber (doctor) so build that and assign an overseer to it. * Within a few days, people will be complaining that they're sleeping below their station and they want a church.  To build either of these, you'll need a ceramics workshop so build it and assign an overseer to it. * You can forgo the church but it just adds more fighting because of cultists. * Settlers DO NOT DEFEND THEMSELVES - EVEN WHEN ARMED. And even if they are eventually stopped, they kill valuable overseers making it impossible to keep up with the overwhelming basic needs of the settlement.End of update-----------------------------------------------------------Have "played" for several hours now. Losing like this would be great if I felt like I had anything to do with it.  Instead, I feel like the devs just have some lazy code in here.FINALFar from intelligent.Far fom done (hopefully).Far from fun.

Early Access Review
								Concept is great could be a good game, but right now its not. Purchased this on a whim and at first its fun and exciting but it wears off quickly with constant crashes (about one every half hour or so) there is not autosave so unless you save manually (which could cause a crash thus negate saving the game) you are SOL. There is no way to deconstruct and some structures will bug out and not work (had my storage area just stop working so no one would stock items there as well as my woodshop just stop producing planks). like I said the game is fun and could go places but there is the folly of early access, most people will buy and never play again due to the bad taste it leaves in your mouth. Heed the steam early access warning and wait for this game to work itself out (if it ever does). Or if you're like me and want to waste $30 because you're bored on a sunday afternoon, have at it.

												TL:DR "Needs work"There is a lot of promise here, but this game is not ready for prime time.  I've been playing since first version was made available on Steam and progress has been made but I would still consider this game in BETA.Some noticeable bugs:* you raise your standing with the Empire (100) so they are sending you Steam Knights to assist... except their weapons are blowing up your enemies AND your colonists to bits * stockpiles keep disappearing (no fun when food stock goes from 600 to 0 in a second)* colonists get stuck in a loop (this happens a lot in a church when 2 citizens are in a confession loop and die of hunger) * with around 75 colonists the AI seems to be wonky at times when all of them pause for few seconds before moving on (not sure if this is due to path-finding issues)Other observations:* Building mechanic needs templates; since i'm going to build a lot of houses with the same layout (6x6 with 2 windows + door + 3 cots) let me save the design into a template and save myself some time on the next build.* there are some cool story elements while you are sand boxing your game but this game needs a single player, story-driven campaign (i.e Settlers 2)* UI is not finished and needs to be more accessible, scrolling through lists is not fun, this isn't excel and i would think most people are playing on 1080p and above by now.
